Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cultures of Sovereignty and Fiscal Order

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Because American Indian nations are not subject to state and local jurisdiction, they also are not subject to municipal property tax codes. In addition, the businesses that they own on sovereign territory are exempt from sales and excise taxes. Residents in non-native communities that surround Indian reservations and other sovereign holdings may find this cause for grievance. Understanding the historic and modern-day circumstances that have brought about these uneasy relationships is important for mitigating conflict. It is also an excellent lens through which to understand the changing meanings of sovereignty, citizenship, and cultural identity in a modern nation state, as they develop through the institution of taxation.

Cornell University graduate student, Emily Levitt, under the supervision of Dr. Paul Nadasdy, will undertake an anthropological case study of the fiscal relations between an Indian nation, their neighbors, and multiple levels of government. The research will be conducted in the upstate New York town of Seneca Falls where the Cayuga Indian Nation has bought land, declared it sovereign territory, established businesses, and claimed tax exemption, thereby provoking both their neighbors and governmental authorities. Because this is an emerging situation that can be well documented as it develops, it is an ideal site to investigate how and why such situations come about and the responses they engender. The investigator will employ a mix of social science research methods, including: participant observation, attendance at public meetings, semi-structured interviews with all stakeholders, archival research, and media content analysis. These data will allow the investigator to understand how taxation affects understandings of who belongs and who does not, as well as the role that fiscal relations play in both Native American and majority culture understandings of themselves and their relationships with others both as individuals and as members of a nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
After having been absent from the area for over two centuries, in the last decade the Cayuga Indian Nation (CIN) has bought over 1,000 acres in the small town of Seneca Falls, NY. Since then, the Nation has refused to pay local property taxes and has refused to collect/remit sales taxes on the products sold at its businesses located on those acres. The Nation's members and legal team argue that they can refuse these taxes because this territory constitutes Cayuga reservation and therefore is not subject to state or local tax codes. They argue that this is the case because the Nation sold this land to New York State under illegal conditions over 200 years ago, and also because the CIN is protected under the doctrine of tribal sovereign immunity. Representatives of Seneca Falls and the larger county, however, use a different legal/historical narrative to argue that the reservation status of this land has been extinguished and therefore the CIN should be subject to the same tax codes as all other local residents. I designed my doctoral ethnographic research project in order to examine how taxation featured as the central rallying point for both sides in demanding a particular political, economic and social order.  

During the study period (September 2013-August 2015), I conducted over 200 interviews and used participant observation on a daily basis. Through these encounters, plus long-term archival research (primarily into the legal background of this fiscal situation, and local media outlets' interpretations of this set of controversies,) I arrived at several conclusions about why the CIN's tax refusals are so symbolically important both to the Nation and to many of the residents of the municipalities that surround the Cayuga reservation. I found that local taxes represent a fundamental aspect of citizenship to many of the non-Cayuga people here, and they also represent the abrogation of sovereignty for the members of the Cayuga Nation.

This disagreement presents a conundrum that would be difficult to fix. Although it offers no specific policy recommendations, this research was designed to help create a better understanding of the stakes held by people on both sides of this debate. This project was successful in that it uncovered many important social concepts that underlie these diverse tax-paying behaviors. This offers a crucial first step in overcoming this tension, which is unfortunately representative of relations between many local and tribal governments.
